text: <@U6BNE7LTZ> BTW, I confirmed that there is no syntax highlighting in the julia notebooks in vscode on my machine.  My bet is that you had manually tried to move those files around sometime and forgot that you had done it.  So, basically, without a resolution to <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/105229>  I don't think we can have syntax highlightin.

text: Right, I have only seen that work on the insider version of the Jupyter extension. Although that was a couple months back, which is why I had assumed things to work fine on stable now

elements.text: Right, I have only seen that work on the insider version of the Jupyter extension. Although that was a couple months back, which is why I had assumed things to work fine on stable now

text:
Yeah, I don't know.  My understanding was that if you fudge the files it should work on both but I could be wrong.  Regarldess, I think this (and the inspector support) are the last of the simple stuff for good notebook integration.  The other issues I pointed out for them (e.g. it wasn't starting in the right folder and hence couldn't activate the project file) were fixed.

I will verify this week that you can now use it without a python/conda installation or the python extension installed after they said they fixed that bug I had found.

elements.text:
Yeah, I don't know.  My understanding was that if you fudge the files it should work on both but I could be wrong.  Regarldess, I think this (and the inspector support) are the last of the simple stuff for good notebook integration.  The other issues I pointed out for them (e.g. it wasn't starting in the right folder and hence couldn't activate the project file) were fixed.

I will verify this week that you can now use it without a python/conda installation or the python extension installed after they said they fixed that bug I had found.
